title.children: 'I have no regrets': Ellyse Perry reflects on decision to pick cricket over football

image.altText: A green and beige camouflaged helicopter sits in shallow water at daybreak at a beach.

title.children: Australian Defence Force MRH-90 Taipan helicopters involved in fatal crash retired early

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: A road train travelling south along the Stuart Highway at sunset, south of Hayes Creek.

props.synopsis: An inquest into the death of a truck driver in WA's north has pointed to the dangers of non-regulation windscreen visors inside heavy vehicles.

title.children: Truckies' sun visors under scrutiny after worker hit and killed at roadhouse

image.altText: A close-up shot of a homemade marker pen gun in two pieces in a plastic ziplock bag.

props.synopsis: A working pen gun, designed to look like a common permanent marker, and a homemade machine gun are among items seized by police during separate raids on outlaw motorcycle gang members.

title.children: Gun disguised as permanent marker found by police during raid in Perth's south

image.altText: Black and white image of Whetoi Pomare

props.synopsis: Aotearoa New Zealand has had a treaty in place for almost two centuries but it wasn't until the 1970s that it was truly honoured. So what happened and what are the lessons for Australia ahead of the Voice referendum?

title.children: New Zealand reneged on its Treaty with Māori. Here's its pre-referendum message to Indigenous Australians

title.children: Michael Gambon achieved an incredible amount before he put his stamp on Harry Potter

props.synopsis: A man who lured a German backpacker to a remote farm with a fake job advert before drugging, restraining and raping her will remain behind bars.

title.children: 'Severe' risk posed by Peter van de Wetering mitigated with indefinite prison sentence

image.altText: Andrews, Albanese and Palaszczuk sit at a long table with some papers talking, with others out of frame.

title.children: Challenging times ahead for Labor and Albanese as another change of state leader looms on the horizon

props.synopsis: Here's your quick pocket guide on daylight saving as Australia comes into the warmer months.

title.children: When does daylight saving start? Here’s what time the clocks go forward and where

props.synopsis: This year's grand final parade, which drew thousands of Brisbane Lions and Collingwood Magpies supporters into the precinct surrounding the MCG, returned to dry land after last year's event made its way down the Yarra on boats.

title.children: Thousands of supporters flock to Melbourne as AFL grand final parade returns to dry land

image.altText: a woman walks past a gallery wall filled with framed paintings

props.synopsis: From designing wrapping paper for department store giant Myer to pioneering art therapy at a Melbourne hospital and adopting digital art, landscape painter June Boase Weller has dedicated a lifetime to the arts.

title.children: 'I can't not paint' 94-year-old woman celebrates a life in the arts

image.altText: A young woman with brown hair stands in front of a wooden drinks bar. She is wearing a long red dress.

props.synopsis: Zoe Nolan remembers how quickly her close friend Abbie White's health deteriorated while they were both battling eating disorders.

title.children: Abbie died from an eating disorder. Her friend Zoe watched her 'disappearing' in front of her

image.altText: A clean-shaven man wearing a blue polo shirt and cat smiles.

props.synopsis: European golfer Viktor Hovland got the Ryder Cup weekend off to a superb start with a rare hole in one — the problem was, it came a day early and wasn't even really a hole in one.

title.children: This golfer hit a hole in one in a par four at the Ryder Cup — here's why it didn't count

image.altText: A group of weaners feeding on hay in cattle yards

props.synopsis: Growers can now make hay while the sun shines after China lifted its two-year ban on hay exports.

title.children: Australian government welcomes China reprieve on hay exports

image.altText: tesla

props.synopsis: The US version of FairWork has launched a lawsuit against Elon Musk's Tesla, alleging "widespread and ongoing racial harassment of its Black employees". Meanwhile, the founder of Evergrande is under police watch, stoking fears the Chinese property giant is about to tank. Read all about today's business news on our live blog.

title.children: Major banks donate $7.75m to Yes campaign, US regulator sues Tesla for 'racial harassment and retaliation'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This table from RateCity is handy. It shows how dominant the big four banks are in the mortgage lending market (loans to both owner-occupiers and investors). RateCity's info is based on APRA’s monthly authorised deposit-taking institution statistics, which were released today for the month of August. CBA (25.6%), Westpac (21.4%), NAB (14.7%) and ANZ (13.3%), account for 75% of the mortgage lending market combined. But interestingly, the total value of household mortgages from Australia’s largest bank, CBA, dropped for the second month in a row. “CBA’s home loan book has gone in reverse over the last couple of months, following the bank’s overt retreat from the refinancing market," said RateCity.com.au research director, Sally Tindall. You can find the link to APRA's lending statistics here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA's loan book shrinks for second month in a row

featuredLink.title: Monthly Authorised Deposit-taking Institution Statistics | APRA

account for 75% of the mortgage lending market combined.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We know this is an economics blog. But we've got a big weekend in sport ahead, with the AFL and NRL grand finals on Saturday and Sunday. And that comes with some economic pros and cons. It is a public holiday in Victoria today, and then a day off for other eastern seaboard states on Monday. Last year when we had a snap one-off public holiday nationally for the Queen's death, one economist told me the total cost to the economy was $2 billion. That was due to all the services suddenly shutting down, as well as the cost to pubs and clubs to pay staff higher wages. You could infer the public holidays across the various states this weekend may have a similar cost, but then you have to consider the financial benefits of sporting weekends. Brisbane hosted both the NRL and AFL preliminary finals, which the Queensland government believes generated $10 million for its economy for just these smaller games. I haven't seen any similar claims from either the Victorian or NSW governments over their hosting of the finals this weekend. But this piece from last year claims that the AFL grand final alone in Melbourne at the MCG last year generated about $50 million in economic activity. UTS economist Tim Harcourt just reiterated that $50 million figure in an interview with Nine, and said that the NRL game has a smaller economic impact, at around $17 million. He added that the AFL impact is probably bigger because the venue it is hosted in, the MCG in Melbourne, is bigger. Which likely therefore draws in more travelling tourists, who then go spending on flights, hotels and extra partying. "I think probably Brisbane airport is the winner," he added, "because you've got the Broncos coming down for the NRL and the Lions coming down for the AFL." Which hints at another story: Queensland may just be the winner overall this weekend! Happy finals fever to all that celebrate.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How the NRL and AFL grand finals impact the economy

children.content: We know this is an economics blog.
But we've got a big weekend in sport ahead, with the AFL and NRL grand finals on Saturday and Sunday.
And that comes with some economic pros and cons.
It is a public holiday in Victoria today, and
then a day off for other eastern seaboard states on Monday
Last year when we had a snap one-off public holiday nationally for the Queen's death,
one economist told me the total cost to the economy was $2 billion
That was due to all the services suddenly shutting down, as well as the cost to pubs and clubs to pay staff higher wages.
You could infer the public holidays across the various states this weekend may have a similar cost, but then you have to consider the financial benefits of sporting weekends.
Brisbane hosted both the NRL and AFL preliminary finals, which the Queensland government believes generated $10 million for its economy for just these smaller games.
I haven't seen any similar claims from either the Victorian or NSW governments over their hosting of the finals this weekend.
But
this piece from last year
claims that the AFL grand final alone in Melbourne at the MCG last year generated about $50 million in economic activity.
UTS economist Tim Harcourt just reiterated that $50 million figure in an interview with Nine
, and said that the NRL game has a smaller economic impact, at around $17 million.

He added that the AFL impact is probably bigger because the venue it is hosted in, the MCG in Melbourne, is bigger. Which likely therefore draws in more travelling tourists, who then go spending on flights, hotels and extra partying.
"I think probably Brisbane airport is the winner," he added, "because you've got the Broncos coming down for the NRL and the Lions coming down for the AFL."
Which hints at another story: Queensland may just be the winner overall this weekend!
Happy finals fever to all that celebrate.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: You may remember that bank bosses appeared last week before a Senate inquiry into the number of bank branch closures that are occurring in regional Australia. They talked about a whole range of things - the shift to digital banking, the future of cash, declining foot traffic, and what impact it has on communities when they lose a bank branch. My colleague Kate Ainsworth wrote a great summary of the topics they covered, which is attached in a link below. But when ANZ chief executive Shayne Elliott appeared in the afternoon, Queensland Nationals senator Matt Canavan asked him how much ANZ had contributed to the Yes campaign. Mr Elliott replied: “It’s been publicly reported that major companies like ANZ have made donations in the region of sort of $2m and we're ­certainly in that range." So we've asked the other major banks what their contribution has been, and here were their answers: NAB : $1.5 million. Westpac : $1.75 million Commonwealth Bank : $2 million That's $7.25 million altogether. NAB Group executive, Shaun Dooley (NAB executive sponsor for the Voice referendum), told the ABC that his bank's decision to support the Voice was made "after listening to the perspectives of our Indigenous colleagues, customers and community partners". “NAB is not telling anyone how to vote but wants people to be informed of the issues around the referendum when making a decision," he said. NAB says $1.3 million of its donation was coming through its philanthropic body NAB Foundation. A Westpac spokeswoman told the ABC that Westpac had long advocated for the constitutional recognition of Indigenous Australians. "We support the Voice to Parliament, while respecting there will be a range of views," she said. "Reflecting this support, we’ve made donations of $1.75 million to campaigns encouraging a yes vote on October 14." A spokesman from Commonwealth Bank said CBA had donated $2 million to Australians for Indigenous Constitutional Recognition (AICR), and it will be disclosed to the Australian Electoral Commission in line with regulatory requirements. He said CBA had a longstanding interest in improving outcomes for Indigenous communities, but it respected that among its key stakeholders there would be a diversity of views about the Voice. "Whatever the outcome of the referendum we will remain focussed on reconciliation and on the steps CBA can take to improve outcomes for Indigenous staff, customers and communities," he said. But again, here's a great summary of the main banking topics that were discussed in the regional bank closure inquiry last week in Canberra:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How much have Australia's major banks contributed to the Yes campaign? Around $7.25 million

featuredLink.title: It costs every Commonwealth Bank customer $40 to keep cash available — but the majority of them don't use it

My colleague Kate Ainsworth wrote a great summary of the topics they covered, which is attached in a link below.
But when

Yes campaign
Mr Elliott replied: “It’s been publicly reported that major companies like ANZ have made donations
in the region of sort of $2m
and we're ­certainly in that range."
So we've asked the other major banks what their contribution has been, and here were their answers:
NAB
: $1.5 million.
Westpac
: $1.75 million
Commonwealth Bank
: $2 million
That's $7.25 million altogether.

NAB Group executive, Shaun Dooley (NAB executive sponsor for the Voice referendum), told the ABC that his bank's decision to support the Voice was made "after listening to the perspectives of our Indigenous colleagues, customers and community partners".
“NAB is not telling anyone how to vote but wants people to be informed of the issues around the referendum when making a decision," he said.
NAB says $1.3 million of its donation was coming through its philanthropic body NAB Foundation.
A Westpac spokeswoman told the ABC that Westpac had long advocated for the constitutional recognition of Indigenous Australians.
"We support the Voice to Parliament, while respecting there will be a range of views," she said.
"Reflecting this support, we’ve made donations of $1.75 million
to campaigns encouraging a yes vote
on October 14."

A spokesman from Commonwealth Bank said CBA had donated $2 million to Australians for Indigenous Constitutional Recognition (AICR), and it will be disclosed to the Australian Electoral Commission in line with regulatory requirements.
He said CBA had a longstanding interest in improving outcomes for Indigenous communities, but it respected that among its key stakeholders there would be a diversity of views about the Voice.
"Whatever the outcome of the referendum we will remain focussed on reconciliation and on the steps CBA can take to improve outcomes for Indigenous staff, customers and communities," he said.
